importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The start date of the last government shutdown, which began on December 22, 2018, and lasted until January 25, 2019, marking the longest shutdown in U.S. history at 35 days.
The date of the most recent update to the article, indicating ongoing political instability and the current federal government shutdown as of October 21, 2025.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame of the 35-day shutdown in 2018–2019, which was the longest in history, affecting economic output and public services.
The current government shutdown, which began without resolution of appropriations bills, is a full shutdown and ongoing as of October 2025.

keyTakeAways: The last government shutdown in U.S. history, from December 22, 2018, to January 25, 2019, lasted 35 days and was the longest in nearly 50 years.
That shutdown cost the U.S. economy an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP according to the Congressional Budget Office (CBO).
The first federal government shutdown occurred in 1976, and since then, there have been six since 1990, indicating a recurring political issue.
The current shutdown is a full shutdown, unlike the 2018 partial shutdown, where only some agencies were funded.
During the 2018 shutdown, about 800,000 federal employees were affected, with approximately 300,000 furloughed and 500,000 exempted from pay but required to work.
The current Congress has not passed any of the 12 required appropriations bills to fund the U.S. government, leading to a full shutdown.
The political environment is highly partisan, with Republican Speaker Mike Johnson leading a narrow House majority and the GOP lacking 60 votes to break a Senate filibuster.
Government agencies are instructed to cease normal operations during funding lapses, resuming when funding is approved.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The source of the article, providing public reporting on the ongoing government shutdown and historical data.

namedEntities.name: Congressional Budget Office (CBO)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provided an estimate of the economic impact of the 2018 shutdown, costing $3 billion in lost GDP.

namedEntities.name: U.S. Federal Government
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The subject of the shutdowns, highlighting dysfunction in governance and fiscal policy.

namedEntities.name: Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Currently overseeing a narrow House majority, contributing to political deadlock in Congress.

namedEntities.name: Senate Filibuster
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A procedural barrier preventing bipartisan legislation, contributing to the inability to pass spending bills and cause prolonged shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: 11th Hour
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Refers to the final moments of negotiations before the shutdown, highlighting the urgency and failure to resolve funding issues.

namedEntities.name: December 22, 2018
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Start date of the last major government shutdown, which lasted 35 days and was the longest in history.

namedEntities.name: January 25, 2019
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: End date of the 2018–2019 government shutdown, marking the conclusion of the longest shutdown in history.
Year when the first federal government shutdown occurred, establishing a historical baseline for future shutdowns.
Year when U.S. agencies began being instructed to stop operations during funding lapses, marking a policy shift.
Current year of the article, indicating a continuation of political gridlock and ongoing government shutdown.

namedEntities.name: 35 days
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The length of the 2018–2019 shutdown, making it the longest in history and a key benchmark.

namedEntities.name: $3 billion
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Estimated economic cost of the 2018 shutdown, illustrating the real-world impact on GDP.

namedEntities.name: 800,000 people
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Total number of federal employees affected during the 2018 shutdown, including both furloughed and exempted staff.

namedEntities.name: 300,000 furloughed employees
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Number of federal employees who were not paid and told not to report to work during the 2018 shutdown.

namedEntities.name: 500,000 exempted employees
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Number of federal employees required to report to work but not paid during the 2018 shutdown.

namedEntities.name: 12 appropriations bills
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The number of bills needed to fully fund the government, which have not been passed, leading to the current full shutdown.

namedEntities.name: partial shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A type of shutdown where only certain agencies remain funded, contrasting with the current full shutdown.

namedEntities.name: full government shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The current situation, where no appropriations bills have been passed and all federal operations are suspended.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article details the ongoing U.S. government shutdown as of October 2025, highlighting that it is a full shutdown due to Congress failing to pass any of the 12 required appropriations bills. It references the 2018–2019 shutdown as the longest in history, lasting 35 days and costing an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP. This shutdown involved 800,000 federal employees, with 300,000 furloughed and 500,000 exempted from pay. The article attributes the recurring political deadlock to partisan gridlock, with Republican Speaker Mike Johnson overseeing a narrow House majority and lacking the 60 votes needed to end a Senate filibuster. The article notes that such shutdowns have become more frequent since 1990, with six occurring since 1990, and points to structural issues in Congress as a root cause of prolonged funding lapses.
title: The last government shutdown was the longest in nearly 50 years. Here are all the recent shutdowns in one chart
